text: awesome thanks so much y'all appreciate
it uh and thanks for being here uh I'm
Dan this is John uh we're going to talk
today about doing deep reinforcement
learning for uh Wildland fire management
um so I'm going to take the first half
John's going to take the second half uh
cool so we both work for a program
called cognitive Mission manager in
locked Martin and uh our goal here is to
develop a suite of uh AI enabled command
and control tools mostly around the use
case of Wildland Fire fighting so what
that means is we're trying to make
decision support tools for the
firefighters uh what we want to do is
either give them recommendations what
should they do either tactically or
strategically or we're trying to maybe
give them like a what if scenario type
thing build a tool that they can try out
a bunch of different approaches to
fighting a fire or something like that
and then see what works see what doesn't
uh this particular project that we're
talking about today um is trying to do
what we call a course of action
recommendation and that really just
means train agents in a simul to fight a
fire if the agents start doing a good
job then you can just take the actions
that the agents do and use those as
recommendations uh and so when we say
course of action generation we just mean
if the agents do a good job at fighting
the fire in the simulation maybe they
could do a good job outside of the
simulation um so the way that we've
tried to model this is based somewhat
Loosely around the actual command and
control structure that the fire services
use uh the way they break it down is
they'll they'll have an incident which
is a fire they'll have an Incident
Commander whose responsible for the
whole fire uh and then that Incident
Commander will divide the fire into
different divisions and they'll put a
division supervisor in charge of each
part of the fire uh that division
supervisor underneath them will have
crew bosses and the crew bosses are
responsible for the day-to-day
operations of choosing where bulldozers
go or uh there's a a unit of guys called
a hand crew which is a bunch of people
with axes and they go and chop down
trees and stuff uh and so those crew
bosses will dictate at the um hourly
level what should we actually go work on
today so we've tried to create a similar
kind of framework uh where we have a
hierarchical RL environment uh we've got
our division supervisors each with a
division that they're responsible for
and then we have like our crew bosses
who are the actual assets that take
action in the world so that would be the
bulldozers and they would do things like
Drive left or you know build a fire line
West or whatever or the crew bosses the
helicopters stuff like that so loosely
inspired by the actual command and
control structure but uh amendable to
reinforcement learning hierarchical
approach okay let me talk about our
simulation uh we have built a simulation
that's basically just a bunch of layers
of geospatial data so we have our
topography we have our um our wind the
actual fire including the heat parameter
and stuff like that uh we have what we
call fuel which is basically the the the
trees and the the the grasses all the
different things that might burn uh
those are classified into different
kinds
of different kinds of um like uh you
know trees burn at different rates it's
harder to cut down other trees so
there's different classifications that
you divide them into um we take all of
those different layers we stack them up
uh and that's our uh that's our basic uh
like world uh We've also developed an
in-house fire uh propagation model uh
John built a lot of that uh it's based
on if anybody knows the rothermel uh fir
spread model and some of the other ones
we've done a sort of we've combined a
couple of models that we like built some
of our own code uh that is what's
responsible for how the fire grows over
the course of our simulation um we've
also taken a bunch of the constants that
matter for this kind of work and we've
used US Forest Service estimates to
things like um how fast can you drive a
bulldozer up a certain level of a
certain grade of of land or like how
hard is it to bang through a redwood
tree with a bulldozer um these are
things the forest service estimates for
us we take those constants we put them
into our simulation uh and all of that
defines our environment uh which we wrap
up in a
an RB multi-agent en um and train our
agents against um so what this looks
like inside of an action Loop uh is we
will have our fire which here is red um
we've divided it into in this case five
divisions radially based on the center
of mass of the fire uh and we'll take
the division supervisors and they will
act collectively to allocate the
resources that they have available to
them across the different divisions so
let's say they have 10 bulldozers on
this particular day the division
supervisors get together and they say
who should get which bulldozers once
those uh bulldozers have been allocated
then each of the division supervisors
takes whatever it has and it places
those assets down into the world we move
down the hierarchy then to the crew boss
who are the bulldozers uh and they get
to decide stuff like should I drive to
the West should I build a fire line to
the north what should I do you know five
minutes from now 8 minutes from now 10
minutes from now they make their actions
we step the world uh and then at the end
of the day we rotate back to the top so
that's our basic training Paradigm um
these will you know we we go until
either the fire wins as in it gets to
the edge of the map or until it's
contained as in it stops growing um cool
so that's our Sim I'm going to turn it
over to John to talk about some of the
ways that we actually train our agents
in this
environment cool thank you Dan um so
yeah I'm going to walk back up the agent
hierarchy starting from the bottom so uh
the bottom level is the crew boss agents
so again these are the ones that are
responsible for actually performing the
fire suppression action so like building
fire line or are dropping water um so
for for these agents the observations
they receive consist primarily of uh
local egocentric uh views into that
geospatial data so so basically they can
see around around their position what is
the the fire look like what is the
topography look like uh what is the the
wind look like um and the reason this is
what we give them is is because like
this is the information that's going to
inform how the fire spreads and then
also what they can do about it so the
sort of suppression Dynamics um then we
also give a bit of supplemental
information on the other nearby agents
which facilitates uh
coordination um and so how do we how do
we train these agents so so we train in
a Cooperative multi-agent setting uh so
so a decentralized pal DP if you're
familiar with some of the RL stuff um
and we train each uh agent that shares
the same type uh with the same
parameters which uh makes the learning a
bit more efficient but we also give a uh
unique agent index to each uh to each
agent that allows it to take on a unique
Behavior if if it's helpful um we also
follow the uh centralized training
decentralized execution Paradigm here so
specifically during training time only
we use a centralized critic that can see
the full state of the world so all of
the uh the geospatial data and also
complete information about each uh agent
and and we find that to be to be really
helpful uh with the training
um so stepping up again to the top level
here um the division supervisor um so
again this the the map of the fire map
is divided into partitions uh or or
divisions um and each is overseen by a
division supervisor um and those
division supervisors really do two
different actions so first they act act
collectively to decide how to allocate
the available crew boss agents amongst
themselves um and then secondly once
they have that allocation they perform
sort of A fine grain placement of those
agents into the world um so for that
first uh first part the allocation
because it's a collective action we
actually train them jointly as as a
single agent um and specifically the way
we do this is uh so for for each
division we take the bounding box around
that division um mask out all
non-division pixels and then um we
compress that information with a
pre-trained auto encoder that sort of
summarizes the important details into a
division embedding and so we train that
outside of the RL process um so now we
have a sort of summary for each division
we stack those on top of each other and
then uh we put that so so that so the
stack represents sort of the full fire
picture um then we put that stack
through a policy Network that uses self
attention to to uh attend to the
relationships between these different
divisions so so that allows the network
to sort of see what is the relative
potential for fire spread across these
different divisions which is is is as
you can tell very important for for
deciding how to make the allocation um
and so we do that with a custom rlb uh
RL module um and then finally the the
the sort of fine grain placement is
performed uh just by a simple uh
heuristic
um okay so so we mentioned a few RB
features already but I just wanted to
call out a couple more here um so we
recently uh migrated to the new rlb API
which actually there was just a talk

it's I think it may be coming out of

unlocked pytorch multi-gpu training um
so as you can probably imagine these
observations are very large uh there
there's a lot of uh layers of geospatial
data um and the dimensions are also
pretty large and especially the
centralized critic which can see the
entire world it's just it just takes a
lot of uh um data to store this uh this
information so training on one GPU this
severely limited our batch size and
we've found so far that uh with po uh
the bigger the batch size the more
stable and also the better agents form
um so being able to do multi-gpu gives
us this easy easy lever to increase that

we very excited about that um we also
use uh Ray tune which works really

of additional lines of config to to run

also and I'll just talk about some of
our results here so far um so because of
the the immense amount of potential
complexity in in this environment we
decided to start by building simple but
still challenging uh synthetic scenarios
to experiment with so this has kind of
let us uh study the uh training Dynamics
a bit and sort of figure out like how to
do RL uh on this environment um so
specifically we we've created a couple
of synthetic benchmarks um so the first
one um we fix all of the environmental
conditions other than the wind um and we
allow the wind to vary um and the second
one we fix everything except the winds
and also and we allow the uh the fuel so
the the vegetation data to to vary um in
simple patterns um so far we've achieved
82% uh containment on on the first
Benchmark and 62% on the second one and
we're continuing to improve these uh
these numbers
um and um so so the the way we actually
uh do do the training here uh because
it's a hierarchical problem we we sort
of proceed in two alternating uh phases
so so first we train the crew bosses
until they reach uh sort of uh a decent
Baseline performance and then we switch
and then from that point we alternate
across the level so we'll freeze the
weights of the crew bosses train the
division supervisors and then sort of
alternate back and forth and we find
that when one agent level plateaus uh
switching to training the other one can
kind of lift the the the sort of colle
active agents out of that plateau and so
we sort of keep doing that until we
reach a global Plateau
um
okay um and so where we to next for our
team so so what we're working on now is
to continue to add in incremental
complexity to these scenarios um also
add additional uh equipment types so so
those results were just for uh bulldozer

helicopters it's Etc so we've been

larger
infrastructure um and ultimately uh so
we've we've collected uh data for about
